results.notes: On dead wood. Cap 4 cm wide with white, free gills that become pinkish. Stipe 5 cm long x 5 mm wide at apex, equal with a bent base, solid but flexible. No discernible odor, taste a bit oily. Flesh white, 6 mm thick over stipe and tapering to ~ 1 mm at the decurved margin. Spore print pink. Last three photos taken about two hours later at home.
On dead wood in mainly Virginia Pine woods with Maple and Oak present.

Cap graysh brown, tough, subviscid when wet; gills cream, thick, fragile, adnate, distant, having lamellula; stipe white, tough, solid; flesh reddening and then blackening when injured

Fongarium: cKc0011
Date: 16.IX.2012
Biotopes: pousse sur sol sous feuillus (Populus) ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau 118 mm Ø, convexe puis largement convexe à subétalé, sec, brun tanne pâle, puis orné de fibrilles et de méchules brunes sur fond pâle, cuticule dépassant la couche de tubes à la marge ;
Face poroïde blanchâtre, brunissant à maturité et au froissement ;
Pores circulaires et petits, 1-4 par mm ;
Couche de tubes déprimée près du pied, concolore à la face poroïde, 08-20 mm de longueur ;
Pied 84 × 19 mm Ø, élargi vers la base, plein, sec, orné de rugosités brun noirâtre sur fond blanchâtre. Il brunit lentement à la coupe. La chaire dans l’apex est lilas pâle à gris pâle ;
Odeur aigre-douce ;
Sporée brune ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0011-0016
Basides piriformes, tétrastérigmates, non bouclées à la base, de 23-26 × 9-10 µm en moyenne ;
Spores subellipsoïdes à subfusiformes, lisses, à paroi mince de 0,24-0,32 µm, à contenu souvent uniguttulé, parfois à contenu granuleux, avec appendice hilaire, et dépression suprahilaire, verdâtres en NH4OH 2,5 , inactives dans le melzer
11,6 [13,9; 14,8] 17,1 × 3,5 [4,1; 4,4] 5,1 µm
Q = 2,8 [3,3; 3,5] 4; N = 35; C = 95
Me = 14,3 × 4,3 µm; Qe = 3,4
Cheilocystides abondamment rostrées, 52,7 × 12,6 µm en moyenne, rarement capitées ;
Pleurocystides comme les cheilocystides, dont l’apex se collapse facilement, parfois largement ventrues de 40,9 × 14,8 µm en moyenne ;
Caulobasides légèrement piriformes, bistérigmates, non bouclées à la base, de 20,9 × 9,3 µm en moyenne ;
Caulocystides clavées-mucronées ;
Trame tubulaire formée d’hyphes parallèles à subparallèles de 3-9 µm de largeur ;
Pileipellis en cutis terminé par des extrémités hyphale ;
Boucles rares et observées dans le stipitipellis (non représentées dans le présent tableau, mais les photos micrographiques sont disponibles sur demande) ;

Déterminé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture
Confirmé vraisemblable par Geoffrey Kibby

Fongarium: cKc0008
Date: 20.X.2012
Biotopes: pousse sur le bois, en touffes sur les souches et le troncs morts de feuillus ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau 40-100 mm Ø, convexe puis étalé, lisse, rouge brique, plus pâle au pourtour, à marge souvent ornée de vestiges du voile partiel ;
Lames adnées, étroites, serrées, blanchâtres, gris olivâtre puis violacées ;
Pied 50-100 × 5-15 mm Ø, égal, crème à l’apex, vineux vers la base, parfois teinté de jaune par endroits ;
Voile partiel presque membraneux, blanchâtre, laissant une zone annuliforme, abondamment bouclées ;
Sporée brun violacé foncé ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0008-0017
Basides cylindriques, à 4 stérigmates, bouclées à la base, 20,1 × 5,5 µm en moyenne ;
Spores ovoïdes à ellipsoïdes, lisses, à paroi mince de 0,2-0,4 µm, avec petit appendice hilaire et pore germinatif tronqué, à contenu granuleux, verdâtres en NH4OH 2,5%
5,4 [5,8; 5,9] 6,4 × 3,2 [3,5; 3,6] 3,9 µm
Q = 1,5 [1,6; 1,7] 1,8; N = 74; C = 95%
Me = 5,9 × 3,6 µm; Qe = 1,6
Cheilocystides abondantes, polymorphes, lécythiformes, parfois lagéniformes, cylindriques, capitées, rarement largement fusiformes, rarement en cheilochrysocystides, 29,1 × 6,4 µm en moyenne ;
Pleurochrysocystides dispersées, subventrues, mucronées, 36 µm x 12 µm ;
Caulocystides absentes ;
Trame lamellaire parallèle à subparallèle ;
Pileipellis en deux couches distinctes : suprapellis formé d’hyphes en rectocutis et subpellis celluleux ;
Boucles nombreuses, observées dans le pileipellis, 8,7 µm de longueur, le médiostrate, 3,2 µm de longueur, le stipitipellis, 4,06 µm de longueur ;
Remarque: Les boucles du pileipellis sont plus grosses (au double) que celles trouvées dans le médiostrate et le stipitipellis ;

Confirmé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture

Fongarium: cKc0009
Date: 27.VII.2012
Biotopes: pousse sur un billot de bois en décomposition ;

Macromorphologie
Chapeau convexe, fibrilleux-feutré, marge légèrement appendiculée des restes véliques ;
Sporée brun rouille ;

Micro
Planche micrographique: cKc0009-0020
Basides cylindriques à largement cylindriques, parfois lagéniformes, tétrastérigmates, bouclées à la base, 24-30 × 6-8 µm en moyenne ;
Spores réniformes (phaséoliformes) vue de profil, avec renforcement central vue frontale, lisses, à paroi mince à légèrement épaissie, de 0,32-0,60 µm, petit appendice hilaire, avec un petit pore germinatif, à contenu uniguttulé, brunâtres, inactives dans le melzer
7,6 [9,1; 9,8] 11,3 × 4,5 [5,4; 5,8] 6,7 µm
Q = 1,4 [1,6; 1,7] 1,9; N = 35; C = 95%
Me = 9,4 × 5,6 µm; Qe = 1,7
Cheilocystides abondantes en touffes, piriformes à largement clavées, subcylindriques, rarement subbecquées ;
Pleurocystides absentes ;
Caulocystides absentes ;
Trame lamellaire subparallèle ;
Pileipellis en cutis, formé d’hyphes superficiels agrégées en faisceaux, bouclées, à paroi mince, presque lisses, aspérulées ou finement rugueuses, 8-15 µm Ø, à cellule terminale un peu cystidioïde, ou légèrement ellipsoïde, avec subcutis formés d’hyphes apprimées, lisses, parfois incrustées, rouille cannelle, plus étroites que celles des faisceaux ;
Boucles observées dans le pileipellis et dans le stipitipellis ;

Déterminé par Claude Kaufholtz-Couture
Confirmé par Yves Lamoureux

Fongarium: cKc0018
Date: 20.X.2012
Biotopes: pousse sur bois pourri de feuillus, parfois apparemment de conifères, souvent en milieux ombragés humides des forêts denses ;

Micro

Cheilocystides polymorphes abondantes en touffes, cylindriques à largement cylindriques, piriformes à largement clavées, sphéropédonculées, parfois subrostrées dont la base est plutôt cylindriques, parfois subfusiformes, parfois subcapitées, arête lamellaire stérile ;

Remarque: Chez certaines basides à une spore, le stérigmate mesure entre 12-20 µm de longueur. La spore peut parfois paraître verruqueuse, mais c’est le contenu granuleux qui lui donne cet aspect; comme si la guttule était verruqueuse. Lorsque la spore est un peu hors foyer, l’endospore apparait, parfois, légèrement métachromatique, rouge pourpré, en Bleu de Crésyl, surtout avec vue au-dessus. La spore apparaît aussi rouge pourpré en vue de profil ou de face, mais on doit mettre nettement l’image hors foyer pour y voir la réaction. Impossible de représenter la réaction par une photo micrographique ;

This unknown mushroom was growing on a live tree in a crack in the bark. It was approximately 5 feet from the ground. The observation took place in October 2015. The mushroom was approximately 10 inches measured side to side. It stood out approximately 6 inches from truck of tree at widest point. It was approximately 2.5 inches thick. The dark brown part of mushroom was soft and spongy. I have been unable to identify from books I have consulted. Would appreciate input regards identification.

As I was hiking up the Alp Bovine trail to the Col de La Forclaz pass that leads to Trient, I first came across the Amanita mushrooms in Observation Amanita sect. Vaginatae sensu Zhu L. Yang (252525). I then continued up the trail and maybe a half hour later found the mushrooms in this post. Then continuing up the trail and maybe another half hour, I found the mushroom in Observation 252551. They may all be the same species at different stages of development.

results.notes: In grass by Black Birch, ~ 18-20’ away from tree. Caps 2-2.5 cm wide. Stipe 3 mm wide at the apex, equal, cartilaginous. Gills attached, Reddish or pinkish white to reddish grey (Methuen 12 AB 2). Gills turned dark brown overnight.No spore print obtained. At first I thought Panaeolus foenisecii but the gill color didn’t match. Then because of the pinkish gills I considered Agaricus but found no matches. It’s a good thing that I’m not in the woods because right now I’m lost.

Found in mixed woods but was closest to Maple, Black Birch and Hemlock.Cap32 mm wide, dry, with an incurved to decurved margin and 5 mm wide white gills. Stipe white, 6.5 long x 5 mm at the apex and tapering downwards until reaching a 5 mm wide basal bulb. Lower portion of the stipe is yellowish brown with fine fibrils /dots present. Stipe solid fibrous and flexible. Odor mild, taste mild. Spore print white.
Found on downed branches. Found several growing. I believe it was a beech branch, but it could be birch. Definetely not a birch polypore.

Conditions dry and this one was growing at the base of an tree, probably an Oak.

Cap 13.5 cm across surface.
Bluing on pores and flesh but fading fairly quickly.
Could not see reticulation on stipe and taste seemed mild.
Could not get a spore print but measured ~ 12 spores;
~10-12 X 4-5 microns.
With the mild taste and cracked cap surface, the Caloboletus marshii ID may be a stretch, although there seems to be some question about the consistency of the bitter taste in the descriptions I’ve read.

Habitat: light, young mixed wood and bushes, Ostrya carpinifolia dominant, some small, young Picea abies, a few very small (< 1 m tall) Fraxinus ornus, no Quercus and Carpinus in the vicinity; sparsely grass overgrown terrain in a mountain ravine; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; base rich, colluvial, skeletal, calcareous ground, very shallow, soil layer on scree, sand and stones; half shade, relatively warm place; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-7 deg C, elevation 745 m (2.440 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil among stones.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, close to the place where the trail to abandoned settlement Na Skalah passes the ravine Sraunk, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: This find was initially determined as Aureoboletus moravicus (Vacek) Klofac, syn: Boletus moravicus Vacek.. Because of some doubts in this determination the location has been revisited and new pilei collected (see Obs. no. 257921). Pilei cuticle shows a hymenophore appearance with erect hyphae composed of ± inflated cells as the most important distinguishing trait for Hemileccinum depilatum (Ref.:2). Also, almost certain mycorrhizal relation with Ostrya carpinifolia (Ref.: 3) (no other grown up trees in the vicinity), calcareous ground and other traits fit well to the descriptions of this fungus.

Description: Two pilei growing together, almost confluent at the base; diameter 15 cm and 5.2 cm, tubes length 15 mm and 10 mm, context thick 23 mm and 12 mm respectively; stipe length 10 cm with 2.3 cm max diameter and 10.5 cm and 2.3 cm diameter respectively, tapering into a rooting base; smell almost absent or very mild, not unpleasant; taste mild, pleasant, a little bit mucous; tubes somewhat bruising darker when pressed on the older pileus; flesh when cut not bruising (also not on the young pileus, which contradicts to Ref.: 8); pilei surface and pore layer barely noticeably sticking when touched (in dry weather). SP light ocher-brown with slight green tint, oac839.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

This was the largest fruiting of any species I have seen. It literally covered the entire front lawn of a suburban residence under two mature oaks. Representative (about average) cap size: 9 cm., dry, glabrous, smooth like fine kid leather. Stipe: 8.5 cm. X 2.3 cm. at base and 1.8 cm. at apex, yellow with tinges of red toward base. Tubes: 4 mm. deep. Flesh at center of cap: 2 cm. 2 pores/mm. Pores bruise blue then turn brown. Flesh and tubes bruise blue instantly on exposure. KOH yellow-orange on cap. Obtained olive-brown spore print.

These mushrooms were growing in yards on the first street back from the Atlantic Ocean, on Hilton Head Island,where there has (finally) been quite a bit of rain. I collected thirteen mushrooms, some of which are similar to one another. I’d really appreciate some help in identifying them, by name and as to whether they might be nontoxic/safely eaten. That number is consistent from photo to photo.

Most don’t look promising, eating-wise, but I’d still like to know what they are. Two especially interest me. Number 9 reminds me of a piece of a lobster mushroom. The place I found it was not the place it grew. It looked like an animal had been munching on it and dragged it away. It would be great if we have lobsters here. Number 10 is really bizarre. It has a bright yellow powder over parts of it. The powder comes off, onto your hand, when you touch it. That particular mushroom doesn’t look appetizing but I’m dying to know what it is (no pun intended). I also saw what looked like a decaying puff ball. It was too mushy to collect. Does anyone know if there could be puff balls in the HHI/Low Country area?

Pied 30-100 × 2-4 mm Ø, égal, parfois légèrement élargi vers la base, très fragile, cassant, creux, finement pruineux au début, glabrescent, humide, avec fibrilles gris blanchâtre sur fond brunâtre, brun olivâtre à gris-brun ;
Chair mince, brun aqueux à concolore au chapeau ;
Odeur et saveur odeur farineuse rance, de concombre, et saveur indistincte, douce ;
Sporée blanche ;

On a near vertical sandstone bedrock plate that has been uplifted. Habitat is a semi-arid annual grassland setting. Aspect is north.

Thallus consists of greyish brown, rounded areoles with thin white pruina giving an overall grey appearance, K- spot test (test done under both dissecting and compound scopes. At 100x, the thallus cortex is brown turning light reddish brown with K, see photo collage. If this is K+ then I need to re-run species ID!). Thallus epinecral layer +/-15µm tall.

Pycnidia uncommon, cryptic, with a black ostiole raised on a cone. Conidia +/-straight, average 15.5µm (20.2µm, 19.3, 12.7, 10.3, 16.7, 15.5, 13.9, 13.3, 17.7).

Apothecia very small <<1mm, 1-2 per areole, immersed and flush with areole to raised, disk black with proper margin dominant and thalline margin reduced but present on outer rim. Margin becoming slightly raised, appears overall darker than thallus (notable on older apothecia), occasionally with a thin white rim on younger apothecia. Exciple with brown cells near top. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium colorless, epihymenium olive brown with green tinge below, K+reddish brown, with thin epinecral layer on top, . Paraphyses moniliform.

Asci immature, oblong-clavate, K/I-. Spores were not mature, simple, hyaline, globose, 8/ascus. Spores measured in asci average 16.1×10.3µm (16.3×12.6, 15.3×9.7, 16.1×9.2, 16.6×9.8.

results.notes:
I forgot about this since unlike all my other observations this wasn’t in a natural area, but instead in my yard.

Also it has a unique property I want to point out to the viewer. This Amanita is immediately in grass and close to a bush with grass multiple meters in every other direction. I realize these should be only near trees and the closest (not pictured) is a large birch roughly 4.5 meters away. However I recently heard from an excellent source that the distance of a trees roots are often double the circumference of their canopy and this tree has a roughly three meter canopy.
on ornamental Prunus sp.

It was warm and humid after two nights of rain. I couldn’t tell if moisture was coming from the mushrooms or just condensing on the bottom surface. They were very wet underneath. The caps were paper thin. Larger specimens had a greenish center.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1005/2016_DSC4931

Habitat: edge of mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Ostrya carpinifolia and Fraxinus ornus dominant trees; almost flat terrain; calcareous, skeletal ground with many rocks; in shade, relatively warm place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 595 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil/humus and small tree roots in a rock crevice.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, below Na Melu place, next to the trail from Trenta 2b cottage and Trenta 2a cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Based on habit and other traits this looks like Panus conchatus. However, some properties are very unusual, if possible at all, for this determination: the mushroom’s substratum doesn’t seem to be wood, color of the pilei may be still OK (although no violet tint at all observed) but spore print is not white (or pale crème) as according to literature but distinctly ocher-hazel-nut color and spores seem a bit too wide. The mushroom(s) grew from a crack of a larger, mostly buried calcareous rock. There was no wooden stump in the vicinity. The crack was 1-1.5 cm wide and filled with humus and some small (max 4 mm in diameter) roots possibly of neighboring dead Picea abies or several Fagus sylvatica trees surrounding the place. I dug about 30 cm deep around the crack and surrounding soil, but there was no massive wood buried at the place (picture 18 shows the crack where the mushrooms were growing). I’ve never heard that Panus conchatus can grow on such a substratum. But what could an alternative determination be?

Three fuzzed ‘stalks’ with partly confluent pilei found; their (across all of them) dimensions 13 × 10.5 cm; the stalks’ length 3-4.5 cm, the largest ‘diameter’ 3.2 cm; SP abundant, ocher- hazel-nut color, oac757, essentially the same color as of gills.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

Macromorphologie
Chapeau 30-70 mm Ø, convexe puis étalé, parfois omboné, subvisqueux, viscidule à légèrement humide, glabre, subhygrophane, jaune au début, puis jaune plus foncé à ferrugineux avec l’âge ou à l’humidité, parfois lavé de vert olive vers le pourtour et jaune rougeâtre au disque, jaune pâle au sec, à marge incurvée, unie, fibrilleuse-subécailleuse à appendiculée, glabrescente ;
Lames adnées à adnexées, larges, serrées, blanchâtres à jaune pâle puis ferrugineuses ou fauve ochracé ;
Pied 40-120 × 4-15 mm Ø, égal à atténué vers la base, flexueux, farci puis fistuleux, fibrilleux-strié, crème vers l’apex, jaunâtre puis devenant graduellement brunâtre depuis la base ;
Voile partiel presque membraneux, blanchâtre à jaune pâle, laissant souvent une zone annuliforme sur le pied ;
Chair épaisse au disque, ferme, jaunâtre ;
Odeur et saveur odeur douce, fragrante ou aromatique, de persil, et saveur amère ;
Sporée brun rouille ;

results.notes:
A few fruiting in grass under a mature oak on residential property. Mature cap: 7 cm; 3 pores/mm. Pore surface bruising light brown. Tubes: 4 mm. deep. Flesh at cap center: 1.4 cm. Stipe: 9 cm. X 2.5 cm. at base and 1.7 cm. at apex. Flesh in stem and cap did not bruise when sliced; however flesh in stipe has a faintly pinkish/violet tinge inherently, whereas the flesh in the cap is a persile white. Additionally the flesh in the stipe darkens to a dingy shade of white after a few minutes of exposure to air while cap flesh remains pristine. Odor is “mushroomy.” KOH negative on cap, flesh and pores but faintly pink on exterior surface of stipe. Stipe also reacts faintly yellow with ammonia. Unable to obtain any spore print.

This appears to be the same species as in Ob. #209237 (found on 7/7/15) and Ob. #244148 (found on 7/12/16) at the exact same site.

This time I was able to also collect an immature specimen, which shows the stipe before it peels and the reticulation as it appears on the stipe in this stage. The last two pictures are of the immature specimen.

results.notes:
Hydnellum concrescens (Pers.) Banker
Cap: 2-6 cm wide (for single mushroom), often accreted by two up to by 7 or more, almost flat or shallow vase-shaped, often asymmetric; concentric coloured: light brown, pinkish-brown and brown (minor yellowish-brown) with outer white ring, indistinct radial hairy; lower side is hairy with short spines, cream-white, brownish or pinkish-white.
Stalk: 2-3 cm long, 2-4mm thick, fine hairy and light brown up to dark brown.
Edibility: stiff as a wood bark.
Habitat: crowded accreted clusters (after hard rains) or small group on the ground with pine needles or on pine roots in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
July – September

Sporée brun rouille ;

Stalk: 6-9cm long, 0.5-0.8cm thick, fine hairy, yellowish-white when young up to brownish-red when old, fibrous and hollow old.
Edibility: no data for this location, published that not edible.
Habitat: small group or crowded clusters on partially rotten stumps or trunks in pine-tree forest with birches.
July – September

Pholiota aurivella (Batsch) P. Kumm., Strophariaceae, Agaricales. (Golden Pholiota, Чешуйчатка золотистая)
Cap: 3-8cm bell-shaped up to convex or broadly convex often with gentle knob or as very broad cone hat; brownish-yellow up to dull orange-yellow with reddish-brown broad scales, sometimes small and rare; sticky in wet weather and some glossy in dry season, often fringed along margin with veil remnants.
Gills: attached and close, narrow up to moderately broad; colour from pinkish-white or cream up to brownish-pink, sometimes pinkish-brown when old and dried.
Stalk: 8-12cm long, 5-10mm thick, fibrous, brownish and dirty yellow up to light yellowish-brown, smooth and silky at the top (1-2cm), tiny yellowish-brown scales below indistinct ring; fragile nearby a ring.
Veil: partial whitish veil, leaving evanescent dull yellowish-brown ring 1-2cm below a cap.
Edibility: good after boiling when young.
Habitat: crowded clusters or small groups on rotten trunks or stumps of deciduous trees (mainly birch) in wet places of mixed pine-tree forest.
Season: July – September.

Very rare species in the Netherlands, bound to wood chips and mulch. I was lucky a friend of mine posted this on facebook and invited me to come over to make photos, notes and a collection for my fungarium!

Description:

Pileus: 20-80 mm; ovoid, then campanulate, later with or without dimpled umbo; first entirely covered with light reddish brown tissue that breaks up into smaller scales when the pileus expands and becomes darker when mature, doesn’t break up in the center, hence the center is darker, surface white at first, later with vinaceous hues; surface finely radially fibrillose-scaly, striate margin; weak yellow bruising.

Lamellae: L: not recorded, l: 3; numerous, crowded, remotely attached from the stipe, narrow; white when young, later yellowish; margin even to slightly fimbriate; reddish bruising.

Stipe: Upto 80 mm; centrally located, irregularly shaped, flexuous, fusiform; entirely covered with the same scales as on the pileus, on a surface concolourous with the surface of the pileus, which in time turns brown with a vinaceous tinge; surface over the entire length sericeous and shiny (under the scales); yellow bruising after scratching, but reddish after handling; annulus narrow, white at first, later darkbrown and collapsed to the stipe, finely floccose on the underside, brownish attachment where it meets the pileal margin, there obviously thicker and more floccose, fleeting.

Context: Marshmallowish in the pileus, soft in the stipe; white, after cutting yellowish in the pileus, reddish in the stipe, especially in the cortex; stipe solid, darker in the foot.

Smell/taste: Mushroomy smell, no flavor.

Ecology: Cespitose, dense clusters of >50 specimens each, three groups on a woodchip path of a dog walking area, probably broadleaf chips, since the mycelium of Chlorocibora spec is everywhere, with Populus standing in the vicinity.
results.location_name: Capelle aan de IJssel, Zuid-Holland, Netherlands

results.notes:
This is the same mystery taxon that I’ve encountered a few times already this season.
A few observations: 1) I’ve only encountered this guy at or very close to the base of Quercus virginiana. It tends to issue forth from piles of leaf litter – piles that are often amassed at the foot of suburban live oaks by rakes. 2) It is not gregarious. One or two fbs is the most I’ve encountered at one site at one time. 3) It shares a similar schedule with Boletus campestris. I tend to see the two on the same days. On days when just about everything else is popping, particularly other boletes, these are absent. 4) I have only encountered this species in suburban areas. While there are plenty of live oaks in the denser wooded areas close to town, this guy seems to favor the solitary old growth trees situated in suburban lawns.
